He hopes the investment will allow him to maximize his production and crop yield. This will be Jose’s first loan from Edpyme Alternativa.

loans.use: to purchase cotton seed, fertilizer, pesticides and other inputs

loans.name: Futuro Para Un Bienestar (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El banco Comunal Futuro para un Bienestar está formado por 10 señoras y 1 señor, quienes son muy alegres y  que con sus diferentes actividades laborales luchan día a día para mejorar la economía de su hogar, viven en diferentes partes de la ciudad de Cuenca, esta ciudad se caracteriza por su hermoso centro histórico, el mismo que fue nombrado en diciembre de 1999 como Patrimonio Cultural de la Humanidad.

La Señora Luisa C. vive por el sector de El Tablón en Monay, este es su primer crédito y fue invitada por una vecina. Se dedica a trabajar en una panadería que es de su propiedad  hace un año, el local es de su propiedad, trabaja de domingo a domingo sin un horario fijo. Aprendió a realizar el pan siguiendo un curso de panadería y también antes de poseer su negocio trabajaba realizando esta actividad. 
Doña Luisa tiene 37 años, es casada y tiene 3 hijos de 16, 14 y 11 años, sus dos primeras hijas  estudian en el colegio y su última hija en la escuela, su esposo la ayuda en la panadería y juntos han logrado construir su casa propia. 
El crédito lo va ha invertir en la compra de harina, mantequilla y mas materia prima para su panadería. Su meta es ser una profecional y salir del pais para trabajar en esta area.

La Señora María Y. vive por el sector San José de Balzay de la ciudad de Cuenca, tiene 30 años, es casada y tiene 4 hijos, sus 3 primeros hijos estudian en una escuela de la ciudad, su esposo trabaja en un taller en donde fabrican carrocerías, no tienen casa propia por lo que viven en la casa de un familiar.
Doña María labora en un comedor, actividad que la realiza desde hace un año, cuenta con un local propio y trabaja de lunes a sábado desde las  9 de la mañana hasta las 8 de la noche.
Este es el primer crédito que realiza en el banco comunal y fue invitada por una amiga, este crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de mesas y sillas. Su gran sueño es tener su casa propia.
texts.en:
The Future for Welfare Community Bank consists of 10 women and 1 man, who are very happy. Working in different activities, they struggle everyday to improve the economy of their homes. They live in different parts of the city of Cuenca, known for its beautiful historic center, the same that was designated in December 1999 as Cultural Heritage of Humankind.
Mrs. Luisa C. lives on El Tablón en Monay district. This is her first loan and she was invited by a neighbor. She owns a bakery for about a year now, where she works 7 days a week. She learned to make bread by taking a bakery course; even before owning her bakery, Luisa already worked as a baker.
Mrs. Luisa is 37 years old, married and has 3 children, 16, 14 and 11 years old. Her first two daughters attend high school and her youngest daughter attends school. Her husband helps at the bakery and together they have managed to build their own house.
The loan is going to be used to purchase flour, butter and other ingredients for Luisa’s bakery. Her goal is to become a professional baker and leave the country to work in this area.
Mrs. María Y. lives in the district of San José de Balzay, in the city of Cuenca. She is 30 years old, married and has 4 children. Her 3 oldest children attend a school in the city. Her husband works at a workshop, doing bodyworks. They don’t have house of their own, so they live in a relative’s house.
Mrs. María works at a diner for a year, which she owns. She works from Monday to Saturday, from 9 am to 8 pm.
This is the first loan she does in the Community Bank; she was invited by a friend. This loan is going to be used in the purchase of tables and chairs. Her biggest dream is to have her own house.

loans.use: Buy flour, butter, eggs, etc/Buy tables and chairs.

loans.name: Santiago

texts.es:
Santiago es un padre D. familia D. 36 años D. edad que resiD. junto a su esposa y a sus hijos en el sector Campiña Compuerta Marcelo del distrito D. Illimo, una distrito agrícoL. que se encuentra situado en L. provincia D. Lambayeque, a cuarenta y cinco minutos D. L. ciudad D. Chiclayo.

Se dedica a trabajar en labores asociadas a L. agricultura desD. que era más joven. Por un lado cría animales menores, especialmente ovejas, en algunos corrales situados cerca a su domicilio. El los alimenta D. granos y pastos naturales, cuando ya han alcanzado un buen nivel D. desarrollo los ofrece en venta a los negociantes que frecuentemente visitan L. zona en donD. resiD.. Adicionalmente trabaja como peón agrícoL. en los diversos campos D. cultivo D. L. zona.

Santiago desea ampliar su negocio comprando más animales y alimento para ampliar su negocio, adicionalmente desea realizar algunas mejoras en sus corrales, para realizar su objetivo ha creído conveniente solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito D. 1800 nuevos soles.

Santiago es una persona emprendedora y que tiene muchas ganas D. salir adelante. Su mayor anhelo es seguir creciendo como empresario y poder otorgarle a su familia una mejor calidad D. vida.
texts.en:
Santiago is 36 years old, and a father.  He lives with his wife and children in the Campiña Compuerta Marcelo sector, which is part of the Illimo district, an agricultural district in the province of Lambayeque, 45 minutes from the city of Chiclayo.

He has worked in agriculture since a young age.  Currently he raises young animals, especially sheep, in pens located near his home.  He feeds them grain and wild grass until they are grown, at which point he offers them for sell to the dealers who frequent the area where he lives.  He also works as a laborer in local fields.

Santiago would like to expand his business by purchasing more animals and feed.  He would also like to make some improvements to his corrals.  For this reason, he has requested a loan of 1,800 Nuevos Soles from Edpyme Alternativa.

Santiago is an entrepreneur with a strong desire for success.  His greatest wish is to grow his business and give his family a better quality of life.

loans.use: To purchase young animals and feed for an animal raising and sales business

loans.name: Heliana Soraya

texts.es: La señora Heliana Santamaría C. es una emprendedora mujer, madre soltera de dos jóvenes de 11 y 15 años. Tiene una microempresa en su casa en la cual elabora deditos, empanaditas, quibbes, caribañolas y arepas de maíz. Estos productos los empaca en bandejas de icopor. Ella aprendió esta actividad por haber laborado durante varios años en una panadería, posteriormente quedó desempleada y consideró que era la hora de crear su propio negocio para sacar adelante a sus hijos. Con el producto de sus ahorros compró un pequeño molino manual, tiempo después adquirió un molino eléctrico y otras máquinas para preparar la masa de maíz y la masa de harina de trigo. Desde un principio sus productos tuvieron una gran acogida, al principio ella los vendía directamente caminando por las calles y ofreciéndolos  “puerta a puerta”. En la actualidad tiene dos vendedores y un empleado fijo que le colabora en la producción. Diariamente la señora Heliana produce 100 bandejas que vende a $ 2.500 y $3.000. El margen de ganancia, luego de haber descontado los gastos, es de aproximadamente el 20%. Con la proximidad de las fiestas de fin de año, las ventas se incrementan considerablemente. Este es el primer crédito que la microempresaria tramita con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo y planea invertirlo así: una parte en  la compra de materias primas como harina de trigo, maíz, queso, levadura, carne, etc. y la otra en materiales de construcción para adecuar el local en el cual funciona el negocio. La señora Heliana se declara una mujer optimista y luchadora que está logrando sacar adelante a su negocio y a sus hijos sin la ayuda de su esposo.
texts.en:
Sra. Heliana Santamaría C. is an enterprising woman and a single mother of two youngsters, ages 11 and 15. She runs a small business out of her home where she makes finger foods, miniature turnovers, “quibbes” (fried pastries stuffed with meat), “caribañolas” (another type of meat-filled pastry made with cassava dough), and corn arepas. Her products are packaged in polystyrene containers. Heliana learned this trade after having worked several years in a bakery. She later became unemployed and felt it was time to start her own business so that she could support her children. Using her savings she bought a small manual grain mill. Afterwards, she was able to acquire an electric mill and other machines for preparing cornmeal and wheat flour. From the beginning her products have been well-received. At first, Heliana sold her products directly to customers by walking through the streets and going door-to-door. She currently has two salespeople and a permanent employee who helps with production. Each day, Sra. Heliana produces 100 trays that sell between 2500 and 3000 COP. Her profit margin, after deducting expenses, is 20%. With the year-end holidays approaching, her sales will increase considerably.

This is her first loan with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo and she plans to invest the funds in the following manner. Part of the money will be used to buy supplies such as wheat flour, corn, cheese, yeast, meat, and other ingredients. The other part will be used to acquire construction materials to renovate the shop where she operates her business. Sra. Heliana is an optimistic and determined woman who is able to succeed in her business and with her children without the help of a husband.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients for her business & acquire construction materials to renovate her shop

loans.name: Yuliana Milagros

texts.en:
Yuliana is twenty-nine years old. She resides with her partner and two children in the district of Saña near the city of Chiclayo. They live in the small town of Centro Poblado Menor Saltur, which is a congregation of homes.

For the past two years Yuliana has raised ducks, chickens and other small to medium sized animals on the land behind her home. This business helps mitigate fluctuations in the family income and provides extra income for the family.

This will be Yuliana’s first loan from Edpyme Alternativa. She plans to use the funds to purchase additional balanced feed for the animals to provide ongoing management of her business and increase the family income. She dreams of being able to put her children through a full course of schooling and, possibly, to send them to university.

loans.use: To purchase additional balanced feed

loans.name: Lider De Defensores Group

texts.es: La Sra. Carmen Raquel es la secretaria del grupo “ LIDER D. DEFENSORES” integrado por diez personas, todas amigas y vecinas D. Ventanilla – Callao Perú. lo que mas le apasiona son los trabajos manuales algo a lo que siempre se dedico en sus ratos libres empezó como una forma D. liberarse del estrés y relajarse un poco, jamás pensó que  esto significaría un ingreso adicional, fueron sus amistades y compañeras D. trabajo las que la animaron a vender lo que ella confeccionaba como sus tejidos, suvenirs, recuerdos. Etc. Para cada ocasión especial prepara manualidades novedosas, ahora esta preparando bolsos naviD.ños ya cuenta con muchos pedidos es por eso que el dinero D. su préstamo lo  invertirá en la compra D. telas para la confección D. los bolsos, también esta considerando alquilar un local para estas fechas naviD.ñas para exponer y vender sus productos ya que cuenta con el apoyo D. su hija que la anima a seguir en el negocio ambas comparten la creatividad y les gusta lo que hacen.
texts.en:
Sra. Carmen serves as secretary of the group “Lider D. Defensores” (Leader of the Defenders), which is composed entirely of women who are neighbors in the Ventanilla area of Callao, Peru. Carmen is passionate about making things by hand and always spends her free time in this manner as a means of relaxing and releasing stress.  She never thought that her hobby would result in extra income.  Her friends and co-workers encouraged her to sell the items she produces such as weavings, souvenirs, mementos, and other crafts.  Carmen produces handmaD. novelties for each special occasion.  Now she is preparing Christmas bags and has already received many orders. 

For this reason, she is requesting a loan to invest in fabrics for making the bags.  Carmen will also consider renting a stand during the holiday season where she can display and sell her products.  She has the support of her daughter who encourages her to continue with the business.  They both share in their creative abilities and enjoy what they do.  

*Sra. Carmen is the seated woman holding a bag.

loans.use: Buy cloth to sew Christmas bags

loans.name: Marily Nallely

texts.es: La joven Marily Nallely R. S. es una mujer muy responsable que aun vive en la casa de sus padres los cuales apoya económicamente. La casa donde la familia vive la adquirieron de interés social la cual es muy pequeña, Marily ya es mayor de edad y desea tener su propio espacio para vivir cómodamente. Por tal motivo pide del apoyo para construir un cuarto.
texts.en: Marily Nallely R. S. is a responsible young woman who lives at the home of her parents, who she supports financially.  Her family home, which was acquired through a government assistance program, is very small.  Marily is the oldest child and wants to have her own space so that she can live comfortably.  Therefore, she is requesting assistance in order to build a room.

loans.use: Begin construction of a room to be added to her family's house

loans.name: Irene

texts.es: La señora Irene Garcia Juárez es una mujer pensionada y apoyada económicamente por sus hijos que viven es los estados unidos. En este momento desea arreglar la tubería de su casa  que esta tirando mucha agua por lo tanto le sale más caro el recibo. Es por ello que desea arreglar este problema lo antes posible para no estar desperdiciando tanta agua.
texts.en: Sra. Irene Garcia Juárez is a pensioner and receives financial support from her children who live in the United States.  At the moment, she wants to repair the plumbing in her house since pipes are leaking large amounts of water, thereby leaving her with expensive utility bills.  For this reason, she wants to fix the problem as soon as possible to prevent wasting so much water.

loans.use: Pay for plumbing repairs

loans.name: Dora Alicia

texts.es: Dora Alicia Rodríguez C. es una mujer divorciada desde hace varios años, actualmente vive con una de sus hijas y dos nietas de otra hija la cual vive y trabaja en los estados unidos para ganar más dinero y enviárselos a sus hijas. La señora Dora desea progresar es por ello que cuenta con un negocio de la venta de comida como lo es hamburguesas y hotdogs, chicharrones y fruta en vaso  desde hace 8 años al que desea invertir en el para obtener mas ganancias.
texts.en: Dora Alicia Rodríguez C. has been a divorced woman for several years.  She currently lives with one of her daughters and two granddaughters from her other daughter since their mother works in the United States to earn more money and sends remittances home to them.  Sra. Dora wants to make progress, which is why she started a business selling food such as hamburgers, hot dogs, roasted pork, and fruit cups.  She has been in business for eight years and wants to invest so that she can generate more revenue.

loans.use: Restock her business

loans.name: Ana María

texts.es: Ana María N. T. cuenta con una miscelánea desde hace dos años donde vende refrescos, abarrotes y mas. Este es su único ingreso es por ello que quiere invertir para incrementar sus ganancias.
texts.en: For the past two years, Ana María N. T. has managed a variety store where she sells soft drinks, groceries, and other products.  This is her only source of income, so she wants to invest so that she can increase her profits.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for her store

loans.name: Dinora Ibon

texts.es:
Dinora Ibon Sánchez G. se dedica a la producción de pasteles que distribuye entre sus amistades y vecinos a un buen precio. Ella es madre de dos mujeres por las que quiere salir adelante a pesar de estar separada del padre de ellas.
Dinora es una mujer emprendedora pero ahora quiere comprar una estufa mejor que la que tiene para seguir con su venta y así generar a su familia un mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Dinora Ibon Sánchez G. produces cakes and distributes them to friends and neighbors for a good price. She is the mother of two daughters for whom she wants to succeed despite being separated from their father.

Dinora is an enterprising woman, but now she wants to buy a better stove than the one she has so that she can continue generating sales and provide a better quality of life for her family.

loans.use: Purchase a stove

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Restock her business with supplies

loans.name: Kil's Group

texts.en:
This group of borrowers consists of four people. Its leader, Mrs. Kil N. (55) is a mother who is blessed with six children: three are married and three are single. Mrs. Kil N. currently generates an income of approximately $2 per day by selling Khmer cake. Her husband is a porter. She is requesting a loan to provide additional capital to buy raw material for making Khmer cake.

There are three other members in this group who have requested loans. They are using the loans for the following activities: 
Mrs. S. is applying for a loan to repair her broken house.
Mrs. R. is asking for a loan to add more capital to her Khmer cake business.
Mrs. N. is applying for a loan to mend her old house (her husband is pictured instead of her).

loans.use: To buy raw material for making Khmer cake.

loans.name: Elsa's Group

texts.en:
Elsa S. is from the village of Looc Libertad Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 25 years old. Elsa is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Luxurious.

Elsa is married and has 2 infants. Elsa owns & operates a seafood store where she sells products such as fish and shrimp. She has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Elsa joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Elsa is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Cecilia's Group

texts.en:
Cecilia P. is from the village of Looc Libertad, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 37 years old. Cecilia is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Luxurious One.

In 2010, Cecilia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Diosdada

texts.en:
Diosdada T. is from the village of Canibungan Daku, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 53 years old. Diosdada is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Diosdada owns and operates a business that provides transportation services. Diosdada has been engaged in her business for over two years, and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2004, Diosdada joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Diosdada has successfully repaid a previous loan of 50,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used for her coconut business. Diosdada is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to repair her existing vehicle so that she can provide better service. This loan will be Diosdada's 13th loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our field partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair her existing vehicle for better service.

loans.name: Francisco

texts.en:
Francisco A. is from the city of San Antonio, Ozamiz City. He is 57 years old. Francisco is married and has six adult children. To make a living, Francisco owns and operates a business that provides transportation services. Francisco has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Francisco joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Francisco has successfully repaid a previous loan from GDMPC, and is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to repair his existing vehicle so that he can provide better service. This loan will be Francisco's fifth loan from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated by the business to improve the general living conditions of his family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To repair his existing vehicle for better service.

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda R. is from the village of Tinaclaan, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 45 years old. Merlinda is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Merlinda owns and operates a business raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting bananas for sale. Merlinda has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2004, Merlinda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merlinda has successfully repaid a previous loan from GDMPC, and is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. This loan will be Merlinda's 18th loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, such as manure.

loans.name: Michille

texts.en:
Michille U. is from the city of Sta Cruz, Tangub City. She is 23 years old. Michille is single. To make a living, Michille owns and operates a business making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from preparing and selling cooked food for daily snacks. Michille has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Michille joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Michille is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase the raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be Michille's first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our field partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase the raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.

loans.name: Ronie

texts.en:
Ronie A. is from the village of Mialen, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He is 31 years old. Ronie is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Ronie owns and operates a business providing transportation services. Ronie has been engaged in his business for over one year and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Ronie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ronie is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to repair his existing vehicle so that he can provide better service. This loan will be Ronie's first loan from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To repair his existing vehicle for better service.

loans.name: Ramil

texts.en:
Ramil L. is from the village of Kinangay Norte, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He is 36 years old. Ramil is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Ramil owns and operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing watch repair services in the local community. Ramil has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2004, Ramil joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ramil has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC, and is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be Ramil's seventh loan from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our field partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service.

loans.name: Nonito

texts.en:
Nonito P. is from the village of Sta. Cruz, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. He is 49 years old. Nonito is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Nonito owns and operates a business that provides transportation services. The main source of income for the business comes from operating tricycle transport services. Nonito is just starting this business.

In 2009, Nonito joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nonito has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for his business. loans.name: But's Group

texts.en:
The Preaek Ruessei village group in Kandal province consists of four members who make up a group loan. Mrs. But S. is the group leader.  She is 30 years old and has been selected by the other members, who use their portion of the loan for different ways to support their businesses. 

She and her husband, Mr. Sokhom Lorn, are farmers who own a four-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support their family. He is also a  fisherman.  

Now is the time to grow rice in their field, but they did not have enough money to support their rice field. So, to improve production, Mrs. But S. is seeking a loan to hire farm laborers and oxen to plow her field. 

She is a mother of two children, one of whom is a student, while the other is 1 year old.

loans.use: To hire laborers and oxen to plow the field

loans.name: Poch

texts.en:
The woman shown in the picture is Poch S., 51, a fisherwoman. She and her husband need to spend eight hours a day to fish, in and around the Tunle Sap River. 

The couple is blessed with nine children: six are single and the three are married and live in their own house. This couple catches around 10 kilos of fish per day and sells them in bulk to their customers who are retail sellers in the market.  

In addition to fishing, Poch S.’s husband also uses his boat to ferry people across the river for an additional fee to support his family. 

Currently, his boat is broken down from usage.  Poch S. will use her loan for her husband to mend the broken boat.

loans.use: To repair broken fishing boat

The members who make up this village bank are twenty-three people who live in Anlong Slat village in Kandal province.

Her problem is that her husband’s fishing supply is too old to use. So, to improve this condition, Mrs. Nouy S. is applying for a loan to buy  a fishing net to replace his old one. 

She is a mother of eight children, two are babysitters who get a low salary, four are studying in the local village, and the others are too young to work or study.

loans.name: Merla

texts.en:
Merla M. is a 47-year-old business-woman. She is married and has one son and one daughter. She lives in the busy town of Binangonan in the Rizal Province of the Philippines. She is the living picture of a mother whose dream it is to give her children a decent life.

Merla joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, in 1998 with dreams of acquiring capital for her planned reseller business. She has been in the reseller business for twelve years now. It brings her enough earnings and continues to grow, and she wants to further invest in her business.

Merla proposes an amount of 20,000 pesos to use as additional capital for her enterprise. Specifically, the loan will be used to pay for inventories of stocks  for resale. She dreams of expanding her business. She also aspires to have a good life in the future.

Merla hopes that one day she will be able to have her own produce stall in the market place, instead of just in her house from where she sells products.  She wishes to be able to make enough to pay for her children's education and dreams the best of life for her family.

texts.en:
Mr. Veasna H. is 49 years old and his wife, Mrs. Chanthy Men, is 47 years old. They live in a small village outside of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have three children: one son and two daughters.
 
Veasna has been a soldier for more than 10 years. His wife stays at home and does housework. One of his daughters is a garment factory worker. She does not have transportation to get to work and she spends a lot of money for traveling costs very often. 

Hence, Veasna is requesting his first loan of US$1,000 to purchase a motorbike for his daughter to drive to work. 

Mr. Veasna H. was not available for the picture, so his wife is pictured.

loans.name: Ma. Lourdes

texts.en:
Ma. Lourdes P. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 32 years old. Ma. Lourdes is married and has seven children. Her eldest child is 12 years old and the youngest is only 5 months. To make a living, Ma. Lourdes owns & operates a business preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals.

Ma. Lourdes joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda P. is from the village of Brgy. La Torre North, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 50 years old. Erlinda is married and has two adult aged children. To make a living, Erlinda owns & operates a general store selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Erlinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erlinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Erlinda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Pouv

texts.en:
Pouv P., 30, works as a professional journalist for a private company located in the middle of Siem Reap province. His wife, Sok Phary, 27, sells a few groceries in her own store in front of her home. They currently live with their parents, who are used-goods sellers. The couple does not have any children.

Pouv P.'s motorcycle is getting old, and usually breaks down during driving. He would like to borrow money to add to his savings to purchase a new motorbike to replace the broken one. With the rest of the loan he will buy more grocery inventory for his wife to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorbike to replace a broken one.

loans.name: Allen

texts.en:
Allen B. is a 42-year-old mother of three children.She is industrious and committed to helping her husband. The hardship she is experiencing today is her inspiration to continue her membership and be able to get higher loans in the future.

Allen joined first Kiva field partner, ASHI attracted by ASHI's lower interest rates and range of loans for business, education, and home repair. Prior to ASHI, Allen had no access to capital to support her entrepreneurial dreams. Allen hopes her ventures will flourish so she can provide long term financial stability for her family.

Allen applied for this loan to engage in a buying and selling of RTW (ready-to-wear-clothes), rice, dry goods and others. She wants to save more money to finance the education of her three children who are already in school. The oldest child is a first year college student and the other two are in elementary school. She promises her group mates to do  good performance to be able to achieve her dreams through the support of ASHI and KIVA.

Allen's one hope and dream is to alleviate her family from poverty. Allen is very pleased to be a Kiva borrower and says thank you for helping fund her business endeavor.

loans.use: To engage in buying and selling business such as RTW (ready-to-wear-clothes), rice, dry goods and others.

loans.name: Suth's Group

texts.en:
The four members who make up this group loan live in Preaek Ruessei village in Kandal province. Mrs. Suth M., 44, is the group leader who has been selected by the other members, each of whom will use their loan for different purposes. 

She and her husband, Mr. Yun Chor, are farmers who own a two-hectare plot of land which they use to cultivate rice to sell to support their family. He is also a construction worker. Now she has to face problems because her field has infertile soil and it is far away from an irrigation system. So, to improve production, Mrs. Suth M. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer and gasoline. She is a mother of three children, all of whom are students.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and gasoline

loans.name: Angelita's Group

texts.en:
Angelita N. is from the village of San Juan, Alicia, Isabela. She is 45 years old. Angelita is the group leader of a 14-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Angelita is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Angelita owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for breeding. Angelita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP monthly for these activities.

In 2007, Angelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Angelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Angelita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Angelita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

To make a living, Jovena owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Jovena has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 3200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Jovena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jovena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Jovena is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Jovena from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

location.town: Brgy. La Torre North, Bayombong,Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma J. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 48 years old. Norma is married and has a 16-year-old child. To make a living, Norma owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals and snacks. One of Norma's goals is to have her child graduate from college and have a bright future.

Norma joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Norma is requesting a loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business and pay for her child's tuition fees.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Srin's Group

texts.en:
Five members make up this loan group located in Chong Preaek village in Kandal province. They will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes in which to improve their living standard. Mrs. Srin S. the group leader is 44 years oldand selected by the other members. She and her husband, Mr. Chhorn Chho, are farmers who own 1.5-hectare plot of land where they grow rice to sell to support their family and he is also a fisherman. She is a mother of three children, two of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory, while the other is a student.

Mrs. S. has a problem cultivating rice as she did have enough rice seed. So, to improve production, Mrs. Srin S. is asking for a loan to buy additional rice seed.

loans.use: To buy rice seed

loans.name: Felisa

texts.en:
Felisa T. is from the village of Brgy, Ibung, Villaverde, in Nueva Vizcaya. She is 54 years old. Felisa is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Felisa owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for breeding. Felisa has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 5300 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Felisa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Felisa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Felisa is requesting a new loan of 23000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Felisa from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Chkuon's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Chkuon A., 52, is the leader of this four person group located in Preaek Andoung village in Kandal province.  Each member will use their portion of the loan for a different purpose. 

She is a widow with a child who is a seamstress in a garment factory. She is a congee (rice porridge) and Khmer cake maker who sells her food and can earn a large profit to support her family. Her problem is that her house is not comfortable to live in. So, to improve this condition, Mrs. Chkuon A. is seeking a loan to buy timber to build her house.

loans.use: To buy timber to build her house

loans.name: Meam's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of four people located in Thmei village, Kandal province. This group selected Mrs. Meam L., 58-years-old, as the group leader. Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan to support their different purpose.
 
Mrs. Meam L. works as an assistant at the commune where she can receive a little salary to support her family. With her job, she needs a computer, but she does not have enough money to buy it. So, she would like getting a loan to buy a computer to support her job activities.  Her husband, Mr. Long Siphann, stays at home. This couple has two children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory and another is employed in the casino club.

loans.use: To buy a computer to support her job activities.

loans.name: Lalaine's Group

texts.en:
Lalaine M. is from the village of Barangay Santa Maria, Dupax del Sur, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 35 years old. Lalaine is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Lalaine is single. To make a living, she raises pigs for breeding. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $118 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lalaine joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. 

Lalaine is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed other supplies. This will be her 4th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

location.town: Brgy. Sta. Maria, Dupax del Sur, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
41-year-old Yolanda T. is a two-year member of ASHI, a KIVA field partner in the Philippines. She resides in a municipality of Binangonan in Rizal province with her husband and their children, who range in age from 10 to 21.  

Her loan from ASHI was used to start up a business she can manage herself so she can have her own income to support her family's needs, especially that of her children. Presently, Yolanda’s income through her sewing business is not yet enough to support her dream of giving her children the best things in life. Her husband’s income is sporadic and insufficient for their support. Therefore, she wanted to request a much larger loan from ASHI to grow her business. With ASHI and KIVA, Yolanda believes that there are a lot of things she can do for her family through her business.

Her long-term goals are for her children to complete college, for the expansion of her sewing business, and to buy more sewing machines for better output. She is very happy to be a Kiva borrower and says thank you for helping fund her venture.

loans.use: to support her sewing business

loans.name: Venancio

texts.en:
Venancio B. S.. is from the village of Barangay Ibung, Villaverde, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 61 years old. Venancio is married and has seven adult-aged children. To make a living, Venancio raises pigs for breeding. He has been engaged in his business for over twenty-five years and earns approximately $140 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Venancio joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 28,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. 

Venancio is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be his 6th loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Pech's Group

texts.en:
These five people form the group loan. They are located in Preaek Hour Kaeut village, Kandal province. This group selected Mrs. Pech S., a 58-year-old married woman, as the group leader. With the loans, they hope to increase their income to improve their families' standard of living.

Mrs. Pech S. is widow with two children who are seamstresses in the garment factory. She is a farmer who owns a field where she cultivates rice and corn for a living. However, she faces a problem because she does not have enough money to support the farm. Thus, she would like to ask for a loan to buy corn seed, fertilizer and pesticide. She would use the rest of the loan to cultivate bananas.

loans.use: To buy corn seed, fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Lyka

texts.en:
Lyka B. is from the village of Barangay Ibung, Villaverde, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 33 years old. Lyka is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she raises pigs for breeding. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $75 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Lyka joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. 

Lyka is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be her 2nd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Sroeung's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sroeung S., a 49-year-old married woman, was selected as the group leader by its five members. They are located in Peam Reang Kraom village, Kandal province.  Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan to buy supplies, equipment and other items to support their different purposes.
 
Mrs. Sroeung S. and her husband, Mr. Soeur Soeun, are farmers who own a 1.7-hectare rice field and a water machine for cultivating rice. However, they do not have enough money to buy supplies to support the farm. So Mrs. Sroeung S. would like to ask for a loan to buy oil for her water machine. 

This couple has three children. Two are laborers, and the other is a student.

loans.use: To buy oil needed for her water pump

loans.name: Ieng's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Ieng S., who was born in 1986, has been selected by the members as the leader of this group loan located in Preaek Samraong village in Kandal province. Each member will use their portion of the loan for a different purpose. 

She is a seamstress in a garment factory where she is able to earn a small salary to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Vanna Chav, is a motorbike taxi driver. Although they both try to work hard, they can earn only a little income.

So, to start a new business and improve her family's standard of living, Mrs. Ieng S. is applying for a loan to buy clothes and shoes to resell. This couple has two children who are both too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy clothes and shoes to resell

loans.name: Skylane Jean

texts.en:
Skylane Jean M. is from the village of Barangay Ibung, Villaverde, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 31 years old. Skylane Jean is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, she raises pigs for breeding. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately $88 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Skylane Jean joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be her 1st loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Bun's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Bun K., who is 58 years old, was selected as the leader of this group loA. located in Preaek Hour Kaeut village in Kandal province. Each of them will use their portion of the loA. for a different purpose.  

She is a banana seller in a local market where she is able to earn a large profit to support her family. Since her business does well from time-to-time, she wants to expand. So, to improve this business, she is asking for a loA. to buy more bananas to sell. 

She is married to Mr. Leng Nav, who is a fishermA., and she has two children who are seamstresses in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy more bananas to sell

loans.name: Saing's Group

texts.en:
This village loan consists of eight members. They are living in Reang Dek village, Kandal province. This village members selected Mrs. Saing C., a 48-year-old married woman, as the village bank president. Each members will use their portion of the loan to support their different purpose.

Mrs. Saing C. earns her living through pig raising. With this business, she does not have enough money to buy pig food for her pig raising. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to purchase pig food for her current business. Her husband, Mr. Eng Mao, owns a threshing machine which it has been rented to villagers for a profit. This couple has four children: one of whom is a fisherman, and others two help their parents on current businesses. The youngest one is attending in the local school.

loans.use: To buy fish food for fish raising.

loans.name: Him's Group

texts.en:
Eight people made up this village bank loan. They are located in Reang Dek village, in Kandal province. This group members selected Mrs. Him S., a 55-year-old married woman, as the village bank president. Each member will use their portion to support their different purposes.

Mrs. Him S. raises fish which she can earn a little income to support her family. She now faces a small problem because she does not have enough money buy fish food for her business. Thus, she would like to ask for a loan to purchase fish food for her current business. With the rest of the loan, she would use to buy fishnets to support her husband's business. Her husband, Mr. Him ChH., works as a fisherman in the local village. 

They have two children who are fishermen and also support their parents' businesses.

loans.use: To buy pig food for raising pigs

loans.name: Tha's Group

texts.en:
This group loan is for four members who are living in Krabau village in Kandal province. They will use their portions of the loan in varied ways to support their families. The members in this group have selected Mrs. Tha M., 31 years old, as group leader.  

Mrs. Tha M. is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her family. Her husband, Mr. Sarat Mak, is a soldier who earns a salary to support his family. She has two children, one of whom is enrolled in the local school while the other is too young to work or study. Currently, her house is not very comfortable because it has no electricity. To improve this condition, Mrs. Tha M. is applying for a loan to buy some electric supplies to connect her house to the electric power lines.

loans.use: To buy electric supplies to connect her house to a power source

loans.name: Uong's Group

texts.en:
The four members of this group loan live in Boeng Kraom village in Kandal province. They will use their portions of the loan for different purposes to  improve their businesses. They have selected Mrs. Uong S. as group leader. 

Mrs. Uong S.  was born in 1964.  She is the mother of four children, two of whom are farmers while the others are attending school.  Mrs. Uong S. and her husband, Mr. Doul An, are farmers who own a seven-hectare plot of land where they grow rice and corn to sell to support their family. They also own a flour machine for rent to anyone who needs it.  

Her problem is that her crop field is far away from the irrigation system, so to improve production, Mrs. Uong S. is requesting a loan to buy gasoline.

loans.use: To buy gasoline

loans.name: Hourt's Group

texts.en:
The seven members of this village bank are located in Reang Dek village, Kandal province. Each member will use her portion of the loan to support her own purpose. Hourt P., a 53-year-old married woman, was selected as the village bank president by its members. 
 
Hourt P. earns her living by raising fish. With this business, she faces a problem, because she does not have enough money to support it. So she decided to ask for a loan to buy fish food. Her husband, Mr. Som Kov, 49 years old, works as a fisherman and also helps in his wife's business activities. This couple has three children. One is a government worker and the others are students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy fish food for raising fish

loans.name: Pel's Group

texts.en:
There are four borrowers who are taking this loan together, and all of them make their living through fishing. The group's leader, Mrs. Pel H., is 35 years old and married. 

Mrs. Pel H. makes a living by selling fish. She sells the fish that her husband catches or that she buys from other fishermen. This couple currentL. earns an average of US $6 a day, and they have been running their business for more than ten years. They have given birth to four children. All four are single, and one of them works in the fishing business as well. 

Mrs. Pel H. will be using her loan from Kiva to purchase nets for her fishing business. The other borrowers also will be using their loans to buy nets.

loans.use: To purchase nets for fishing business

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes U., a 50-year-old single woman who lives in the island village in the town of Binangonan, Rizal Province in the Philippines, is a woman of courage who maintains hope in her ability to rise above poverty.

Lourdes joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, in 2009, and during her membership, she has been noted for her exemplary performance in meeting her obligations in the organization. Her previous loans were carefully used as rolling capital for her sari-sari (variety) store business. Because this venture allows her to earn just enough income for her needs, she recently ventured into operating a food stall, an enterprise that will bring her enough profit to save for the future.

Now requesting her third loan of 15,000 pesos to purchase more grocery inventory and to support her food stall business, Lourdes is hopeful that the trust and opportunity given by ASHI and KIVA, coupled with hard work, will allow her to reach her dreams of expanding her business, sending her nephew to school until he finishes college, and building a new and more spacious house.

Lourdes is very happy to be a Kiva borrower and says thank you for helping her to reach her dreams.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery inventory and support her market stall

loans.name: Sao's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sao S., born in 1963, has been selected as group leader by the four members who comprise this group loan located in Peam Reang Kraom village in Kandal Province. The members will use their portion of the loan for different purposes.

Sao and her husband, Mr. Savat Bou, a policeman who earns a low salary, support three children, one of whom is a laborer, while the others are attending school. Sao is a farmer who owns a one-hectare plot of land upon which she cultivates rice to sell to help support her family. Although it is now time to grow rice, she lacks sufficient seed and so is requesting a loan to buy rice seed.

loans.use: To buy rice seed

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Triwana Sari Group

texts.en:
Ni Ketut Juni A. is a 27-year-old woman living in the town of Melaya - Bali.  Ni Ketut Juni is the group leader of a 16-member group loan offered by MUK.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Triwana Sari (PK-10353).


Ni Ketut Juni is married and has one school-aged child.  To make a living, Ni Ketut Juni owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale.  Ni Ketut Juni has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 350,000 IDR a month from these activities.


In 2010, Ni Ketut Juni joined MUK to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Ni Ketut Juni has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,500,000 IDR from MUK.  This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.  She is now requesting a new loan of 1,500,000 IDR which will be used to invest in expanding the business.  This will be the 2nd loan taken out by the borrower from MUK.  Ni Ketut Juni plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.


About MUK:

The mission of Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) is to assist small businesses in Bali by providing training, business consultation, and loans, thereby helping the owners and their families improve their everyday lives.





Ni Ketut Juni A. (0) merupakan 27 tahun wanita.  Dia (perempuan) tinggal di kota Melaya - Bali.  Ni Ketut Juni adalah pemimpin kelompok sebuah kelompok peminjam yang terdiri atas 16 anggota.  Meskipun setiap anggota kelompok menerima pinjaman perorangan, mereka semua bertanggung jawab untuk mengembalikan pinjaman rekan anggota kelompok mereka jika ada yang menunggak atau gagal membayar.  Nama resmi kelompok peminjam ini adalah Triwana Sari (PK-10353).


Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber utama penghasilan bisnis tersebut terutama berasal dari beternak babi untuk dijual.  Ni Ketut Juni sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dari 10 tahun.  Dari kegiatan-kegiatan ini, Ni Ketut Juni menghasilkan sekitar 350,000 IDR.  Dalam 2010, Ni Ketut Juni bergabung MUK untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan  -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis.  Ni Ketut Juni telah berhasil melunasi pinjaman sebelumnya sebesar 1,500,000 IDR dari MUK.  Pinjaman sebelumnya ini digunakan untuk membeli bibit ternak untuk dibesarkan & dijual di masa mendatang.  Dia (perempuan) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 1,500,000 IDR.


Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 2nd pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dari MUK.


Tentang MUK:

Misi Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) adalah untuk membantu usaha kecil di Bali dengan memberikan perlatihan, konsultasi bisnis, dan pinjaman uang, dengan demikian membantu pemilik usaha dan keluarga mereka memperbaiki hidup sehari-hari.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Poak

texts.en:
Mr. Poak R., born in 1980, is a villager in Thmei village in Kandal Province. Married to Sarun Ly, they have three children, one of whom is a student, while the others are yet too young to work or study.

He and his wife are farmers who own a small piece of land upon which they cultivate rice to sell to support their family. Although they work hard, they can earn only a small income, so to improve the family's living standard, Poak is requesting a loan to buy an agricultural machine to rent to villagers who need it.

loans.use: To buy an agricultural machine

loans.name: Myla

texts.en:
Mayla, who is 38 years old and happily married, has four dependent children. She operates a store and retails rice in a nearby village and is requesting a loan to buy supplies for her store and to support her rice business.

With her loan and profits, Mayla hopes to be able to afford to send her children to school until they achieve college degrees. Mayla, who had a previous loan with ASHI, was on time in making all of her repayments and so is able to request more for this loan. She is very glad to be a Kiva borrower and expresses her gratitude to lenders for helping fund her two ventures.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for her store and to support rice retail business

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth U. is from the village of Brgy. Ibung, Villaverde, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 30 years old. Elizabeth is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Elizabeth owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for breeding. Elizabeth has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 3200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Elizabeth joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elizabeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Elizabeth is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Elizabeth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Saumu

texts.en:
Saumu is a married woman with four children, three of whom attend school and one of whom dropped from school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor running water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees for her children. 

For over two years, she has been making and selling deep fried potatoes from her home. Her customers are neighbors, passersby and local students. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. Saumu hopes to establish a restaurant in the future and sell different types of food. 

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase 20 litres of cooking oil, a bundle of wheat flour and a sack of charcoal. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase 20 litres of cooking oil, a bundle of wheat flour and a sack of charcoal.

loans.name: Glorina

texts.en:
Glorina is optimistic that her sewing business will produce a steady income to improve her economic stability and her family’s quality of life. Her long term dreams are to continue funding her children’s education and to have a successful tailoring shop someday. Glorina would like to receive a loan to purchase inventory (including fabric cottons and other materials needed) to continue her sewing business.

As a member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, Glorina is thankful for access to loans to support her dreams.

loans.use: To pay for fabric cottons and other materials needed in her business.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

She has operated a vegetable and fruit selling business for over four years, selling by retail from home to her neighbours. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. During the hot summer season, the supply of vegetables in the market is low compared to winter rainy season where supply is very high. Amina hopes to add more stock of vegetables for resale in the future.

With the KES 30,000 she wants to purchase a bundle of vegetables and fruits. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase a bundle of vegetables and fruits.

loans.name: Nou

texts.en:
Mrs. Nou S. is a 57-year-old married woman living in Phnom Penh City. She owns a piece of farmland that she inherited many years ago from her grandparents. She uses this land to grow different kinds of crops. She has nine children, four of whom are single; one is supported by her while the other three are employed as construction workers. Five children are married and have been living in their own homes for a few years now.

 Mrs. Nou S. has a life partner in her husband who is working at a school as a guard. In the past, Mrs. Nou S. was working at repairing her old house. Presently, her house is repaired, but she lacks funds to pay for the repair. So she would like to ask for a loan to pay the costs for repairing her house.

loans.use: To pay for repairing house

texts.ru: Рахмонова Людмила проживает в районе Шахритус. Возраст, 38 лет. Замужем, имеет 3 детей. Образование среднее. Работает на центральном рынке района Шахритус. Она арендует торговую точку, где продает конфеты и печенье. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 5 лет. Кредит берет для увеличения ассортимента товара. На полученную прибыль хочет отремонтировать дом.
texts.en: Lyudmila R., 38, lives in Shahritus. Lyudmila is married with three children. She has secondary education and works at the central market of Shahritus. Lyudmila rents a retail outlet, where she sells candy and cookies. She has been running this business for five years. Lyudmila would like to get a loan in order to increase the assortment at her outlet. The profit would allow her to renovate her home.

loans.use: to increase assortment
