loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and pesticide to cultivate rice.

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean has been dedicating herself to expanding her business in order to support her dreams to improve her family's quality of life. She would like to increase her weekly income and therefore has applied for a new loan of 9,500 PHP to purchase more stocks of charcoal and increase her working capital. She will be very responsible with her obligations and she is thankful to the people who will support the loan she is requesting, which will be very helpful to make her business grow further so that her four children fulfill their dreams of completing college degrees and finding stable jobs.

Jean has already had previous loans from ASHI and repaid them successfully; therefore, she is being trusted with a much larger loan. As an active entrepreneur, Jean would also like to explore more businesses to provide her family with a good living and to invest in land to build a comfortable home to live in. She is very pleased to be a Kiva borrower and says thank you for helping fund her business dreams.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of charcoal and increase her working capital

loans.name: Margie

texts.en:
Margie A. is from the village of Wadya, Banisilan, Cotabato. She is 49 years old, married and has 5 adult-aged children. Margie owns and operates a business providing motorsikad or habal-habal services with her husband as the driver to local community members. Margie has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2008, Margie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Margie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase tools needed to provide service. Margie is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of the motorsikad. This will be the 11th loan taken out by Margie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of the motorsikad

loans.name: Pheng

texts.en: Fishing is the most important part of 49-year-old Mrs. Pheng N.’s daily work. She and her husband have been living on the river for more than nine years. They always catch around 8 kilos of fish a day and sell them to their regular customers who retail in the busy market. Pheng N. and her husband also support their four children, three of whom are single and one of whom is married and lives independently. This approaching fishing season, the river is full of fish, but Pheng N. lacks tools for fishing. Therefore, she is applying for a loan to purchase additional fishing equipment in order to support her business activities.

loans.use: to purchase additional fishing equipment

loans.name: James

texts.en:
B. James is a hard-working and determined gentleman from Ntungamo. He is 48 years old and is married with 5 children, 3 of whom are still in school. 

James has a retail shop that deals in general merchandise in Park Yard, Ntungamo Municipality. In the shop, he works closely with his family and he is able to make genuine profits from his sales. In order to boost his income, James is also involved in the sale of matooke, milk and coffee. He needs a loan to be able to restock his 10-year-old shop with more merchandise so that he could increase his profitability. 

James says that he began his retail shop with proceeds from his agricultural sales business. His dreams and future plans are to be able to acquire a land title as well as expand the business so that he would be able to educate his children.

loans.use: To restock merchandise for resale

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz A. is from the village of San Jose, Mahinog,  Camiguin Province. She is 58 years old and single. Luz owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, junk food, detergents and beverages in the local community. Luz has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Luz joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luz has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to invest in expanding the business. Luz is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and to increase working capital. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Luz from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and increase working capital

loans.name: Soy's Group

texts.en:
The twenty-three people who form this village loan, located in Preaek Ta Ker village, Kandal province, have selected Ms. Soy Y., 29 years old, as the village bank president. All members of this village loan will use their portions of the loan to support their different purposes. 

Ms. Soy Y. is single and earns her living by cultivating corn and peanuts. She works very hard but still lacks money to support her farming. Therefore, she would like to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and peanut seed. Aside from farming, Ms. Soy Y. also works as a deputy to the village chief, receiving a small salary to help support herself.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and peanut seed

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 29-year-old single man from Lebanon. He has 10 years of experience working as a farmer. He has owned his own farm since 2007.  He works independently on his farm and he lives on his own. He learned this occupation from his father and after his death, he took over the operation of the land. He cultivates all type of vegetables according to the season. He also uses plastic tents to grow his products. Today he is requesting a loan of $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase needed supplies for his agriculturA. work. He is a first-time Kiva borrower and a first-time Ameen client. He estimates that the loan will help him increase his profits by 15% for the coming harvesting.

loans.use: To purchase supplies needed for his agricultural work

loans.name: Marita

texts.en:
Marita D. is from the village of Bonbon, Sagay, Camiguin Province. She is 30 years old. Marita is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Marita owns & operates a business fishing and selling fish like sardines, milkfish, barungoy, panit, kutob & squid in the local community. Her husband is the fisherman. Marita has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Marita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to buy and sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Marita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to buy and sell

loans.name: Sirochidin

texts.ru: Каландаров Сирочидин житель города Турсунзаде. Возраст, 54 года. Женат. Отец четверых детей. Образование среднее – специальное, агроном. По профессии работает более 30 лет. Кроме того занимается растениеводством. При доме имеет земельный участок, где выращивает овощи и сеет пшеницу. В этой области уже 10 лет. Кредит берет для закупа семян. Он намерен расширить свою деятельность.
texts.en: Sirochidin K. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda.  He is 54 years old, married and a father of four children.  He has a secondary-specialized education, as an agronomist.  Sirochidin has been working in his field for over 30 years.  Besides this, he is involved in agriculture.  He has a land plot at his house, where he grows vegetables and plants wheat.  He has been in this field for 10 years.  Sirochidin is requesting this loan for the purchase of seeds.  He intends to expand his business.

loans.use: Purchase of seeds

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
In 2008, Alma joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI partner of KIVA in the Philippines. With her first loan, she ventured into the retail selling of charcoal. Charcoal is the most common means of cooking foods for the poor people living in very remote areas of the province. Aside from its affordable price, it is also the most conveniently accessed commodity for everyone from their distant village.

She had observed the demand for charcoal in the market and knew that selling charcoal would bring them enough profit for their day-to-day living. Now on her second loan, she is requesting 9,500 pesos as additional capital for her business. The loan will be used to pay for inventory of charcoal. Alma is hopeful that, with the financial access that she has from ASHI, she can improve her business and make it grow.

Alma came from a poor family. During her childhood, she dreamed of finishing her studies, but due to financial shortages, she was not able to make it. Now, her dream for her own children is to send them to school until they finish college and find jobs, so that they will not suffer the life that she had. She hopes that her business will grow and be sustainable, and is looking forward to having a space at the market someday. She aspires to have her own house and lot in the future.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal to sell

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is a single man who owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. For over a year, he has been wholesaling and retailing clothes at the market and to his neighbours and passersby. James faces a major challenge of seasonality in his business, and his greatest monthly expense is transportation.

Hoping to increase his stock, he is requesting a loan of Kshs 20,000 to purchase a bale of clothes and shoes for resale. James decided to join Yehu to get loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase a bale of clothes and shoes for resale.

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina M. is from the village of Umayco, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 36 years old. Marina is single. 

To make a living, Marina owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from making and selling viands like chicken and pork adobo, afritada & pancit bihon in the local community. She is also running her retail store. Marina has been engaged in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. 

Marina is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Marina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients to make food for sale

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 19-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives with his parents and two brothers. Despite his young age, he has six years of experience working as a farmer. He has owned his own farm since 2007.  He works independently on his farm. 

He learned this occupation from his father; he used to help him in cultivating his land. He cultivates all type of vegetables and fruits according to the season. Lebanon is known by its multiple seasons, that’s the reason why it is always possible to find a variety of products year-round. He also uses plastic tents to grow his products. 

Today, he is requesting a loan of $500 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase needed supplies for his agriculturA. work, such as fertilizers and seeds. He estimates that the loan will help him increase his profits for the coming harvest.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and seeds for farm

loans.name: Mi's Group

texts.en:
Four people are forming this group loan. They are located in Vihear village in Kandal province. This group selected Mrs. Mi Yeth, a 35-year-old married woman, as the group leader. Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan to support their different purpose.

Mrs. Mi Yeth is a farmer who owns 1.10-hectare of rice field to cultivate rice. For this farm, she does not have enough money to support it. So she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to cultivate the rice, and the rest of the loan she want uses it to purchase fishing nets to support her husband's  fishing. 

Her husband, Mr. Sot Soeng, works as fisherman where he earns a little income to support his family. They have four children who are students in the local school and also help their parent's occupations.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to cultivate rice & fishing nets for fishing

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en:
Mr. Sopheap P. (in the photo) and his wife, Mrs. Mon Dav, have been married since 2003 and have two young daughters. All of them are in school. They live in a small village on National Road Number Two about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Sopheap is a mason. He also assists his wife in her rice farming business when he is free. He had asked for a Kiva loan once before, he now is asking for his second loan of $500 to add to his own money to purchase a motorized hand tiller to use on the rice farm.

Sorry inconvenience, the first loan has been posted in the wrong location (Kiva ID 100082).

loans.use: To buy a motorized hand tiller to use on rice farm.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy is a married woman with one child, who attends school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food for the family and rent bills.

She has operated a salon and cosmetic shop for over seven years, selling to her neighbours and passers-by. She faces a major challenge of delayed payments from creditors who purchase goods on credit. Mercy hopes to establish another business of selling clothes in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase body lotions, hair conditioner, hair weaves, and shampoo. She decided to join Yehu to get loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To buy supplies for hair salon business

loans.name: Peter Biwott

texts.en:
Peter Biwott L., a 32-year-old gentleman, married and the father of two children aged five and two years, lives in Kapsowar- Eldoret. The family's sole breadwinner, Peter has operated a butchery business for five years, earning a profit of about Kshs 20,000 every month.

Peter, a KADET client for a while now, is requesting his second loan after repaying the earlier one well and on time. He is planning to use the amount to buy two cows for his business and hopes to make a profit which he will use to boost his business.

Peter's future plan is to open other branches in order to improve his family's living standards.

loans.use: To buy two  cows .

loans.name: Clemantine

texts.en: Clemantine is 28 years old. She is married and has three children between the ages of one and six. Two of her children go to school. Her husband works as a taxi driver. Clemantine has been selling beans and sorghum for six years. She is requesting this loan to buy more beans and sorghum to sell. With profits from this business, Clemantine is planning to renovate her house and put the rest into savings. She says that her business is successful and as a result she managed to buy a motorcycle. In the future, she would like to see her business grow up to 90%.

loans.use: to buy more beans and sorghum to sell

loans.name: Seraphine

texts.en: Seraphine is 24 years old. She is married and has two children between the ages of one and three. None of her children go to school. Her husband works as a motorbike and bicycle mechanic. Seraphine has been selling sugar, rice and bicycle spare parts for five years. With this loan she will increase her inventory. She will save some of the profits in a bank and use the rest to renovate her house. She says that her business is valuable because it helped her purchase land for crop cultivation. Her dream is to have a bigger business.

loans.use: to buy more rice and sugar to sell

loans.name: Gueripine

texts.en: Gueripine is 44 years old. She is married and has seven children aged between 7 months and 25 years old. All her children go to school except the youngest. Her husband works as a businessman. Gueripine has been selling cattle for nine years. She is requesting a loan to buy more cattle to sell. With the profits, Gueripine is planning to build a business structure where she would temporarily keep her cows before she sells them. She says that her business is successful and as a result she has been able to purchase a taxi motorcycle which also serves as another source of income. In the future, she would like to have larger loans to expand her business even more.

loans.use: to buy more cattle to sell

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia is a 37-year-old married mother blessed with three children, John, James, and Jeremy, all of whom are dependent and in need of her support. This situation is the reason Cecilia wants to expand her existing charcoal sales business.

Her business started when she joined Ahon Sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI). Although the sale of charcoal earns income, it only supports the family's daily needs, not other expenses such as the education of her three children. Cecilia really dreams of her children earning college degrees through her hard work and, of course, with the help of her husband. That is why she is requesting her sixth loan from Ahon Sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI), which she will use for the expansion of her ventures. She wants to buy more charcoal to earn more income.

Cecilia also plans to begin a hog-fattening business in order to earn a much higher income. She really wants a better life for her family, and that is why she never stops seeking ways to achieve it.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal

loans.name: Hudoykul

texts.ru: Хасанов Худойкул проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 51 год. Женат, имеет 7 детей. Образование среднее. Более 8 лет занимается растениеводством. При доме имеет земельный участок, где выращивает овощи. Кредит берет для закупа семян. Он хочет посеет и получить хороший урожай для продажи.
texts.en: Hudoykul H. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda.  He is 51 years old, married and has 7 children.  He has a secondary education.  Hudoykul has been involved in agriculture for over 8 years.  He has a land plot at home, where he grows vegetables.  He is requesting this loan for the purchase of seeds.  He wants to plant and gather a good harvest for sale.

loans.use: Purchase of seeds

loans.name: Gulbaira's Group

texts.en:
Gulbaira J., 42, is the leader of this group. She lives in the town of Toktogul, famous for having the biggest water reservoir in Kyrgyzstan. She is married and has three children. Gulbaira owns a small shop where she sells groceries, helped by her 17-year-old daughter. In the past six years, she has managed to open a shop and build a temporary building by her house. She would like to use this loan to increase the circulation of goods and add office supplies to her shop. If she succeeds, she plans to open a bigger shop. 

Microcrediting helps poor regions of the world increase entrepreneurship and have steady employment.  Microcrediting is a source of future growth, ending poverty and gaining credibility in the mainstream of the finance industry. It builds income and wealth and eliminates poverty. Microcreditors build trust and help during difficult times. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase goods for sale

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa is 42 years old and married with three children.  She says that their life is the picture of a poor family.  Because of lack of income, their children get a low level of education. Her eldest son Michael, 18 years old, attained only under high school; John, age 17, attained only 3 years of high school, and the youngest Melvin, 15 years, is in second year high school now. All of her siblings are still dependent on her.

Marissa’s source of income comes from selling biscuits.  That gives them a small income due to the small amount of capital in her business.  Her income is not enough for their daily expenses. 

When Marissa joined Kiva field partner, Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI), she used the loan to increase her working capital for more inventories of biscuits.  Now, the business is giving her income that helps her whole family. But she wants this business to grow more, so she decided to use her new loan in ASHI to buy more supplies for better output.

Marissa is really caring of her three children and her family; she wants to help them and to be happy in her simple way. That’s why she is concentrating in her business so it can give her more income for the entire family.

Her long-term goal is to have jeepney (small bus) in the future for her husband to operate for added income so they can improve their standard of living, because currently they live in poverty.

loans.use: To buy more biscuits to sell

loans.name: James Kibii

texts.en:
James Kibii K. is 42-years-old and married to Hellen Chebii, who sells second hand clothes. He is a businessman who operates a retail shop on a busy street of Kapsowar in Eldoret Town. He has been running this business for the past three years.

He learned about KADET from a friend who is already registered as a client. This will be his second loan. He is planning to increase his stock by buying six boxes of cooking oil, five bags of sugar, and any other stocks needed. With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan he plans to rent a permanent shop. 

James believes he is hard working and he only needs the resources to attain his goals.  In the future, he hopes to grow his business and build a house and be running the shop on his own premises.

loans.use: To buy oil, sugar, and othe stocks for resale

loans.name: Joyce Jemaiyo

texts.en:
Joyce Jemaiyo K. is 30 years old.  She is married to Edwin Kosgei Kiptoo who is a farmer and is a source of additional income for the family. They have three school-going children.  Their residence is in Kapsowar in Eldoret.

She operates a general shop and has been in this business for three years, earning a monthly profit of Kshs 10,000.

Joyce learned about KADET LTD through marketing awareness done in the area.  She is applying for her fifth loan of Kshs 30,000 from KADET LTD, which she intends to use to buy three boxes of cooking oil, three bags of sugar, two boxes of washing powder, and any other stock that need to be added.  With the anticipated profits, she plans to expand the shop business.

In the future Joyce wishes to own rental houses. Her deeper desire is to see her children realize their goals in life through better education.

loans.use: To buy oil, sugar, washing powder, and other stocks for resale

loans.name: Nazokat

texts.ru: Муратова Назокат проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 32 года. Замужем, имеет 3 детей. Муж на заработках в России. Сама Назокат имеет среднее образование. Работает на рынке "Дехкон". Арендует торговую точку, где продает лепешки (национальный хлеб). Этим видом деятельности занимается более 10 лет. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en: Nazokat M. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda.  She is 32 years old, married and has 3 children.  Her husband works in Russia.  Nazokat has a secondary education.  She works at the "Dehkon" market, where she leases a retail stand and sell flat bread (national bread).  She has been involved in this business for over 10 years.  She is requesting this loan in order to increase product turnover.

loans.use: Increasing product turnover

loans.name: Hezekina

texts.en:
Hezekina is 36 years old and married to Francis Wairegi. They have three dependent children and her husband contributes to the family income. She has been running the business for four years with an income of Kshs 7000 a month.

She is taking her fourth loan with KADET to buy stock of sugar, flour, rice to increase food production for sale. She hopes to improve the living standards of the family and educate her children.

loans.use: To buy stock of sugar, flour, rice to increase production

loans.name: Athanas Waweru

texts.en:
Athanas is 65 years and married to Rachael. They have two children.  He has been in this business for about six years, earning a monthly profit of about Kshs. 10,000. Some of the items he sells include torches, manila ropes, radios and others.

He wants to use the money to buy more stock of new items like plastic basins, buckets and jerry cans to sell. This is his fourth loan with KADET LTD. He hopes to live a good life with his wife and to see his grandchildren prosper in life.

loans.use: To buy plastic basins, buckets and jerry cans to sell

loans.name: Review Daniel Ngure

texts.en:
Daniel is 56 years old and is married to Elizabeth with whom he has three children. He has been in the dairy business for ten years now, making a profit of approximately KES 10,000 per month. 

Daniel wants to buy a cow with this loan, and with his savings he hopes to expand his tea farm and start a poultry farm. He hopes to become a well established farmer able to supply more than 200 litres of milk a day. In addition, Daniel wants to see his children attain their goals in life.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is 46 years old and is married to Mary Nyambura with whom he has three dependent children. He has been doing   horticulture farming for one year with an income of KSH 11,350.

This is his first loan with KADET, and with his future savings he wants to increase his farm production by adding more land. Francis also hopes to own a passenger service vehicle and improve his standard of living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and fungicides.

loans.name: Kipkurui

texts.en:
Kipkurui is a farmer from the town of Litein in the Rift Valley of Kenya. He has been farming for four years and employs one farmhand. His mixed farm produces maize and tea which he sells locally. He also earns income from his bodaboda (motorcycle transport) business in the same area. His biggest challenge in farming has been diseases which affect his production.

Kikurui is 22 years old and single. He has requested this loan of 29,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help improve his living standards. In the future, he would like to build a modern dairy unit for his cows.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Mary Maghema

texts.en:
Mary Maghema, 30 years old, is single. She sells clothes, handbags and fabrics for making clothes at Kitengela market, a very busy market. Many of her customers are employees from the surrounding factories and they like her clothes. She was introduced to Kadet by a credit officer.

Mary has been running her clothes business for two years and her monthly profit is KES 8,300. After she gets this loan. she will use KES 2,000 to buy fabric, KES 5,000 to buy handbags and KES 5,000 to buy dresses for sale. If the loan boosts her business, Mary plans to expand the business and turn it into a big boutique.

In the future, she hopes to expand her business and have a stable source of income. Mary is hardworking and focused.

loans.use: to buy fabrics, handbags and dresses for sale

loans.name: Wilson Kimutai

texts.en:
Wilson Kimutai S. is 38 years old and lives in Kapsowar, Kenya. He is married to Rose Rono, who is a businesswoman. They have three school-going children, aged 15, 10, and 6 years old.
 
Wilson's general store is a source of additional income for the family. He has been operating his retail shop for ten years and earns a monthly profit of KES 15,000. Wilson learned about KADET LTD through marketing awareness done in the area and he is applying for his second loan of KES 80,000. He intends to buy goods such as cooking oil, bags of sugar, washing powder, crates of soda and crates of bread. With the anticipated profits, he plans to expand his secondary business, a dairy farm and cereal business.

In the future, Wilson wishes to have a lorry to use for transportation. His greatest wish is to see his children realize their goals in life through better education.

loans.use: To buy cooking oil, sugar, washing powder, soda and bread

loans.name: Bukasa Developement Group-Mukono

texts.en:
Edward S. is 52 years old and belongs to the Bukasa Development Group in Mukono. He is a father to four and for the last four years he has been running a bricklaying and sand-mining business in Bukasa, Mukono. Edward earns 600,000 shillings a month. He also gets some additional money as a farm manager. He says he is going to use this loan to pay his laborers.

Edward's future plan is to buy land for his family and also increase the production of bricks.

loans.use: To pay his workers' wages.

loans.name: Mario

texts.es:
Mario pertenece al banco comunal “El Progreso” de la comuna de Puente Alto. Él tiene una vidriería en su casa desde hace  8 años, en donde fabrica espejos, ventanas, ventanales y shower-doors, entre otras cosas. Tiene como cliente frecuente una mueblería y muchos clientes particulares. 
Con este préstamo comprará materiales. Su sueño es cambiar su vehiculo por uno mejor, lo que para él es muy difícil ya que tiene una deuda en otra institución. 
Vive con su esposa y sus 2 hijos menores de 14 y 8 años. La esposa de Mario trabaja con Fondo Esperanza y su negocio es la venta y arriendo de disfraces.
Para Mario, Fondo Esperanza ha sido un apoyo, principalmente por la facilidad con la cual entregan los préstamos y por las enseñanzas sobre cómo administrar su dinero. Además ha aprendido algunos términos de negocios, lo que le da mayor seguridad. 
Puente Alto es una comuna ubicada al norte de Santiago, capital de Chile. Fue fundada como un pequeño pueblo rural a fines del siglo XIX, pero dado su crecimiento demográfico es actualmente una de las comunas con mayor población de Chile, superando los 600 mil habitantes. Es la puerta de entrada a uno de los sectores precordilleranos de la región Metropolitana, conocido como el Cajón del Maipo, sector con espacios de caminatas, cabalgatas, rafting, entre otras actividades y servicios de alojamiento y alimentación.
texts.en:
Mario belongs to the communal bank "El Progreso" in the community of Puente Alto.  For 8 years he has had a glass workshop in his house, where he constructs mirrors, windows and shower doors, among other things.  A furniture workshop is a frequent customer, along with many individuals. With this loan he will buy materials.  His dream is to get a better vehicle, which is very hard for him since he already has a debt with another institution. 

He lives with his spouse and his 2 children, ages 14 and 8 years.  Mario's wife works with Fondo Esperanza and her business is selling and renting costumes.  

For Mario, Fondo Esperanza has been a source of support, primarily for the ease with which they give loans and for what they have taught him about managing his money.  He has also learned some business terms which gives him greater security.  

Puente Alto is a community located north of Santiago, the capital of Chile.  It was founded as a small, rural town at the end of the 19th century, but given its demographic growth, it is currently one of the largest towns in Chile with more than 600,000 inhabitants.  It is the port of entry to one of the Andean foothill sectors of the metropolitan region, known as el Cajón del Maipo, which has hiking, horseback riding and rafting, among other activities, as well as lodging and restaurants.

loans.use: Materials

loans.name: Pamela

texts.es:
Pamela forma parte del banco comunal “Los Conquistadores”  de la comuna de Puente Alto. Ella vende ropa para el hogar usada, como por ejemplo: toallas, cortinas, sábanas y cobertores, en un puesto en la feria, 4 días a la  semana, incluidos todos los fines de semana, desde hace 3 años. Con este préstamo comprará mercadería y también incluirá ropa interior usada. 
Su sueño es tener un local establecido, para así poder atender más días y más horas, ya que además de tener mayores oportunidades de venta, tendría más comodidad, al no tener que llevar y traer cada día su mercadería. Su principal motivación es terminar de ampliar su casa, en donde vive con su esposo. 
Pamela está muy contenta trabajando con Fondo Esperanza, ya que ha sido un importante aporte para su negocio y para motivarse a seguir creciendo.
Puente Alto es una comuna ubicada al norte de Santiago, capital de Chile. Fue fundada como un pequeño pueblo rural a fines del siglo XIX, pero dado su crecimiento demográfico es actualmente una de las comunas con mayor población de Chile, superando los 600 mil habitantes. Es la puerta de entrada a uno de los sectores precordilleranos de la región Metropolitana, conocido como el Cajón del Maipo, sector con espacios de caminatas, cabalgatas, rafting, entre otras actividades y servicios de alojamiento y alimentación.
texts.en:
Pamela is part of the communal bank "Los Conquistadores" in the municipality of Puente Alto. For three years, she has sold used household linens, such as towels, curtains, sheets, and blankets, at a market stand four days a week, including weekends. With this loan she will buy merchandise and will also include used undergarments.

Her dream is to have a permanent shop, so that she could be there more days and more hours. Along with having greater opportunities for sales, this would be more convenient, on account of not having to carry her merchandise back and forth every day. Her principal motivation is to eventually enlarge her house, where she lives with her husband.

Pamela is very happy working with Fondo Esperanza, since they have been an important contributor for her business and for motivating her to continue growing. Puente Alto is a municipality located to the north of Santiago, the capital of Chile. It was founded as a small rural town at the end of the nineteenth century, but due to its demographic growth, today it is one of the municipalities with the largest populations in Chile, surpassing 600,000 inhabitants. It is the gateway to Cajón del Maipo, one of the foothills areas of the Metropolitana Region, with hiking trails, cavalcades, and rafting, among other activities, as well as food and lodgings.

loans.use: Merchandise

loans.name: Biyabu

texts.en:
Biyabu is a single woman with one girl who attends school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, clothing and school fees. 

She operates a  Leso (Kikoi's) selling business from home to her neighbours and passersby.  In additional she owns a rental house that contributes to her other source of income. Biyabu faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She hopes to expand and build more rental houses in the future. 

With the KES 40,000 she wants to purchase bags of cement and timber to expand her rental houses and pay for the installation of electricity in her rental houses. She decided to join Yehu to access loans and improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase bags of cement and timber to expand her rental houses and pay for the installation of electricity in her rental houses.

loans.name: Antony

texts.en:
Antony N., aged 32, operates a grocery and a general shop at Umoja market. He is married to Jackline Minoo and together they have two sons aged ten and two years who are in Class 4 and Baby Class. 

Antony was introduced to KADET by existing KADET clients. Antony has operated his general shop for three years, which gives him a monthly profit of around Kshs 19000. The grocery gives him Kshs 2000 per month.

Umoja is a well-populated area, and Antony’s business does well. With the loan he intends to open another shop and employ someone to run it. If the loan helps to boost business, Antony plans to open a salon for his wife.

In future Antony wants to be a prominent businessman with many shops and to give his children a quality education. He describes himself as honest and hardworking.

loans.use: To open another shop in Umoja

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah is 30 years old and is married to Ibrahim who alsw contributes towards the family income. Together they have two dependent children. Hannah has been running her grocery shop for nine years, with an income of Kshs 7400.

She is taking out her third loan with KADET to increase the stock of vegetables and fruits. She hopes to expand her business to improve her standard of living and to accumulate some savings.

loans.use: Buy more stocks of fruit and vegetables

loans.name: Marta

texts.es:
Marta forma parte del banco comunal “Un Desafío para Todos” de la comuna de Puente Alto.  Ella tiene un bazar y paquetería en su casa,  desde hace 7 años, en donde también vende alimentos para mascotas. 
Con este préstamo comprará una máquina congeladora de helados y mercadería. Su meta es tener más variedad de productos en su negocio. Su sueño es comprar un auto, para facilitar el proceso de las compras de la mercadería. 
Marta agradece el apoyo de Fondo Esperanza, a través de los préstamos y la educación, destacando entre los temas, cómo administrar su negocio. También valora las amistades que ha ganado dentro de su grupo. 
Puente Alto es una comuna ubicada al norte de Santiago, capital de Chile. Fue fundada como un pequeño pueblo rural a fines del siglo XIX, pero dado su crecimiento demográfico es actualmente una de las comunas con mayor población de Chile, superando los 600 mil habitantes. Es la puerta de entrada a uno de los sectores precordilleranos de la región Metropolitana, conocido como el Cajón del Maipo, sector con espacios de caminatas, cabalgatas, rafting, entre otras actividades y servicios de alojamiento y alimentación.
texts.en:
Marta is a member of the communal bank "A Challenge for All" in the town of Puente Alto. She has run a bazaar and a parcel service out of her home for the last 7 years. She also sells pet food. With this loan, she will buy an ice cream machine and other merchandise. Her goal is to have a wider variety of products for her business. Her dream is to buy a car in order to purchase the merchandise for her business more easily. 

Marta appreciates the support that Fondo Esperanza has given her through their loans and educational classes, especially their business administration class. She also values the friendships she has made through the group. 

Puente Alto is a town located to the north of Santiago, the capital of Chile. It was founded as a small rural town at the end of the nineteenth century but due to its large demographic growth, today it is one of the most populous towns in Chile with more than 600,000 inhabitants. It is the port of entry to the metropolitan section of the Andean foothills, known as the Cajón de Maipo. This sector is known for its hiking trails, horseback riding and rafting as well as its hospitality industry.

loans.use: Ice cream machine and merchandise

loans.name: Salama Development Group 1-Mukono

texts.en:
60,000 shillings is what this decade-long coffee sales business generates for this enterprising and high-spirited 46-year-old business man. He goes by the name of K. William and belongs to Salama Development group-Mukono. It was inspiration from a close acquaintance that got him started in this trade which he has been operating at a food market in Salama-Mukono. 

His previous cattle selling business undertaking was of much help in providing the financial backing as he started. He still ekes out profits from it, though coffee selling is now a first fiddle business. With this loan he says he is going to restock his store with bags of coffee that he says he will resell. He envisions greater prospects for his business in the near future.

loans.use: To purchase coffee for resale

loans.name: Albert

texts.en:
Albert H. is 28 years old. He lives in Sevan with his wife and four-year-old son. 

For about six years Albert has been engaged in animal breeding. His farm includes cows, sheep and chickens. His wife helps him a lot with the farming and in this way they support their young family. Albert and his wife hope to develop their farm in order to earn more income in the future. This will allow them to look ahead confidently, because they plan to have a second child in the near future.
 
Albert is asking for a 400.000 Armenian Drams loan to buy one more cow for his farm and fodder for his cows and sheep.

loans.use: To buy one more cow for his farm and fodder for his cows and sheep

loans.name: María

texts.es:
María forma parte del banco comunal “Esperanza y Fe” de la comuna de Independencia. Ella se dedica, desde hace treinta años, a la confección de diversos productos según encargos, desde cosas pequeñas hasta ropa de hogar (sábanas, cortinas, etc.) y ropa de fiesta. También confecciona cojines bordados con perlas y bordados en cinta. 
Con este préstamo comprará tela para cojines y manteles, cinta y dejará dinero para los encargos  de este mes. Su sueño es ampliar su taller, ubicado en su casa y darle trabajo a otras personas. También quiere ahorrar para su vejez. El trabajo de María es la única fuente de ingresos en su hogar y con éste mantiene a sus 2 hijas: de 20 y 18 años. 
María está muy agradecida de Fondo Esperanza, ya que, a pesar  de estar endeudada en otra institución, confiaron en ella y le dieron los préstamos, teniendo así la oportunidad de emprender en su negocio, con buen comportamiento de pago. Además le han servido los talleres, en los que ha aprendido, especialmente el que dice relación con cómo administrar el dinero. 
Independencia es una de las 34 comunas que componen la ciudad de Santiago (capital de Chile), ubicada en el sector centro-norte. Se caracteriza por la presencia de edificios de mediana altura. Aquí se encuentra el Centro Cultural Indígena de Chile, entre otros 6 monumentos históricos de Chile.
texts.en:
María is part of the community bank "Esperanza y Fe" (Hope and Faith) in the community of Independencia. She devoted the last thirty years in the making of various products according to orders, from small things to household linen (sheets, curtains, etc.) and party clothes. She also manufactures cushions embroidered with pearls and ribbons.
With this loan she will buy fabric for cushions and tablecloths, ribbons and leave money for this month’s expenses. María’s dream is to expand her shop, located in her home and give work to other people. She also wants to save money for her retirement. María’s work is the only source of income of her family and has to be enough to support her and her 2 daughters, who are 20 and 18 years old.
María is very grateful to Fondo Esperanza because, although she is in debt to another institution, they trusted her and granted her the loans she needed, giving her the opportunity to engage in her business, with good payment. She also had the opportunity to attend workshops, and learn in particular how to manage money.
Independencia is one of the 34 communities that make up the city of Santiago (the capital of Chile), located in the central-north. It is characterized by its medium height buildings. Here lies the Indian Cultural Centre of Chile, among 6 other historical monuments of Chile.

loans.use: Buy fabric and ribbons

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
Juana pertenece al banco comunal “La Granja”  de la comuna de La Cisterna. Su negocio es un almacén y bazar, en donde también tiene juegos de máquinas. Comenzó como sociedad hace más de un año, pero hace 2 meses se independizó. Antes de este negocio, Juana, vendía comida rápida. 
Con este préstamo comprará mercadería para el almacén y guardará dinero para comprar juguetes, papel de regalo y cintas para vender en la época de Navidad. Su sueño es tener una casa propia, ya que vive con toda su familia, compuesta por su esposo y sus 3 hijos de: 17, 15 y 6 años, en la casa de su mamá. Además quiere tener su negocio en la misma casa, ya que hasta ahora arrienda un local. 
Para Juana, Fondo Esperanza es como una familia, ya que en su grupo, gracias a los temas de solidaridad y respeto inculcados por la asesora, han creado vínculos, unidad  y apoyo entre ellos.
La Cisterna es una comuna de Santiago, ubicada en el sector centro-sur de la capital chilena, y comprendida totalmente dentro del área urbana. Es una comuna esencialmente residencial y comercial.
texts.en:
Juana belongs to the communal bank “La Granja” (The Farm) in the community of La Cisterna.  Her business is a store and bazaar where there are also game machines.  She began as a member over a year ago, but two months ago she became independent.  Before this business, Juana sold fast food.
With this loan she will buy merchandise for the store and will save money to buy toys, wrapping paper, and ribbons to sell during the Christmas season.  Her dream is to have her own house as she now lives with her whole family, made up of her husband and their three children who are 17, 15, and six-years-old, in her mother’s house.  Additionally she would like to have her business in the same house as now she is renting a commercial space.
For Juana, “Fondo Esperanza” (Hope Fund) is like a family, as in her group, thanks to the themes of solidarity and respect instilled by the leader, they have created links, unity, and support among the members.  
La Cisterna is a community in Santiago located in the central-south sector of the Chilean capital and completely within the urban area.  It is a community that is mainly residential and commercial.

loans.use: Merchandise

loans.name: Judith

texts.es:
Judith forma parte del banco comunal  “Esperanza y Fe” de la comuna de Independencia. Su negocio consiste en la venta, arriendo y confección de disfraces y trajes típicos, en su casa, desde hace 3 años. 
Con este préstamo comprará materiales para confeccionar trajes, colgadores y  bolsas para cubrir los disfraces. Su sueño es tener una empresa de eventos, como cumpleaños y matrimonios con servicio integral (coctel, decoración y animación) y de esta manera mantener un bienestar económico para su familia. Tiene 2 hijas de 7 y 2 años.
Para Judith, Fondo Esperanza ha sido un importante aporte en su negocio, que le ha permitido crecer y mejorar sus condiciones de vida.
Independencia es una de las 34 comunas que componen la ciudad de Santiago (capital de Chile), ubicada en el sector centro-norte. Se caracteriza por la presencia de edificios de mediana altura. Aquí se encuentra el Centro Cultural Indígena de Chile, entre otros 6 monumentos históricos de Chile.
texts.en:
Judith is part of the communal bank “Esperanza y Fé” (Hope and Faith) in the community of Independencia.  Her business consists of the sale, rental, and production of costumes and typical dress.  She has worked out of her house for three years.
With this loan she will buy materials to make costumes, hangers, and bags to cover the costumes.  Her dream is to have an event-planning business, like birthdays and weddings offering full service (drinks, decorations, and activities) and in this way maintain the economic well-being of her family.  She has two daughters who are seven and two-years-old.
For Judith, “Fondo Esperanza” (Hope Fund) has made an important contribution to her business that has enabled her to grow and improve her quality of life.  
Independencia is one of the 34 communities that make up the city of Santiago (the capital of Chile).  It is located in the central-north sector.  It is characterized by the presence of buildings of medium height.  Here you can find the Centro Cultural Indígena de Chile (Indigenous Culture Center of Chile), among six other historic monuments of Chile.

loans.use: Fabrics, hangers, and bags.

loans.name: Salama Development Group 2-Mukono

texts.en: 34-year-old K. Patrick is affliated with Salama Development group-Mukono. A decade has now elapsed since he began his retail shop venture in Salama-Mukono.  He says he began this trade with the urging of a close associate, and at length, as he has operated, it is diligence that has brought success within his grasp. Patrick says he, by and large, relied on finances from his earlier farming business to start up this business. 150,000 shillings is what accrues to his business as weekly profits. With this loan, he says he is going to purchase more retail stock to resell.

loans.use: The purchase of more retail stock to resell

loans.name: Somos Un Complemento Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal “Somos un complemento” es conformado por 22 socias, pertenecientes a la ciudad de Puerto Varas. Sus principales negocios son la venta de ropa, frutas y verduras; producción de mermeladas y frutas en conservas; tejidos en telar y servicios de peluquería, terapias y masajes estéticos.  
Verónica, quien en la foto se encuentra en última fila, en 1º lugar de izquierda a derecha y tiene el pelo corto, se dedica al servicio de manicure y pedicure hace 4 años. Este rubro lo aprendió sola y obtuvo un certificado a través de un curso que tomó por Internet. Con este préstamo comprará los materiales que le faltan para seguir con la construcción de una sala para atender a sus clientes en su casa, ubicada en el patio trasero. También atiende a domicilio. Verónica estima terminar su sala el próximo año. 
Su sueño es crecer en su negocio y mantenerlo en su casa para estar más cerca de sus dos hijas, de 11 y 4 años y cuidar de ellas, ya que el negocio es el principal sustento económico de su familia. 
A Verónica le ha servido mucho el apoyo económico de Fondo Esperanza y también disfruta mucho al compartir con sus compañeras ya que todas comparten el  sueño de surgir.
Puerto Varas es una comuna ubicada al sur de Chile, en la región de Los Lagos, a orillas del Lago Llanquihue. La ciudad se ha destacado siempre por su relación con el turismo, ofreciendo hermosos paisajes naturales, buena comida, playas, parques naturales. También  es conocida como “la ciudad de las rosas”, por la profusión de rosales plantados en sus calles.
texts.en:
The communal bank “Somos un complemento” (We Are the Complement) is made up of 22 members from the city of Puerto Varas.  Their main businesses are the sale of clothing, fruit, and vegetables; production of jams and fruit preserves; weavings, services like hair-dressing, massage, and beauty therapies.  Verónica, who is in the last row, first on the left, with short hair in the photo, has worked giving manicure and pedicure services for the last four years.  She learned this skill by herself and obtained a certificate through a course she took on-line.  With this loan she will buy the materials that she is lacking to continue with the construction of a room to attend to her customers in her house which will be located in the back patio.  She also does house calls.  Verónica estimates that she will finish her room in the next year.
Her dream is to grow her business and keep it in her house so that she can be closer to her two daughters who are 11 and four-years-old so that she can take care of them, as her business is the main source of income for the family.  The economic support from “Fondo Esperanza” (Hope Fund) has helped Verónica greatly and she also enjoys sharing with her fellow members as all share the same dream to grow.
Puerto Varas is a community located in the south of Chile, in the Los Lagos region on the banks of the Llanquihue Lake.  The city has always been known for its tourism, offering beautiful natural landscapes, good food, beaches, and nature parks.  Also, it is known as the city of the roses because of the many rose plants in the streets.

loans.use: Construction materials needed to build a room.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is 45 years old and divorced with five dependent children. She has a green grocery in an open air market. She has been in business for three years with a monthly income of Kshs 7400.

She is taking her second loan with Kadet to add stock of green vegetables and fruits. She hopes to accumulate her savings and buy a plot of land to develop. She also hopes to educate her children and have a good life.

loans.use: To buy vegetables and fruits for resale

loans.name: Kiganda Development Group-Mukono

texts.en: N. Sarah saw the counter-productive effects of poor planning, ineptitude and the hasty rush for financial returns on her close friend’s ill-fated businesses that she says taught her a lesson.  She made deductions that the above factors contributed to the unraveling of her friend’s businesses. It is for that reason that 6 years ago, she decided to begin her cosmetics selling business on a totally different slate. Sarah has come to terms with the fact that hard work, focus, and constant planning are invaluable for the success of any business. Sarah, who belongs to Kiganda Development group-Mukono, says credit goes to her mother for the support in starting this business. Previously she was operating a charcoal and water selling business. This mother of 3, who is happily married, says her weekly profits total up to 100,000 shillings. With this loan she says she is going to purchase more cosmetics to resell.

loans.use: The purchase more cosmetics to resell

loans.name: Stephen Kabati

texts.en:
Stephen is 47 years old and is married to Mary Wairimu.  They have three children. Stephen has been in the poultry business for a period of two years with a monthly profit of about Kshs 12,000.  

Stephen has no history with any other micro finance institution and was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend. 

He will use the loan to buy poultry feeds. The accumulated savings will be used to expand his farming activities. He hopes to educate his children and improve his family's standard of living.

loans.use: To buy poultry feed

loans.name: Alice J

texts.en:
Alice J. K. is 41 yrs old and is married to a teacher, Ezekiel K..  She is a mother of five: Maureen (17 years), Dorothy (14), Robert (12), Naomi (10), and Harriet (3).

Alice subsidizes her husband's income in supporting her family. She has been milling maize for the last year. Her business gives her an average profit of Kshs 10000. 

This will be Alice's third loan with KADET, as she has  successfully repaid her first and second loans.  Alice intends to use Kshs 20000 to purchase maize and millet stock for milling and use the remaining Kshs 50000 to complete her rental houses.

Alice anticipates using profits from the business to pay back the loan and develop her family's land. Her hopes and dreams are to expand her milling business to cover the whole Baringo district and give her children the best education possible.

loans.use: To purchase maize for milling business and complete rental houses

loans.name: Azinafa

texts.en:
Azinafa has been practicing mixed farming for the last eighteen years in Kitale town, western Kenya. Her mixed farm produces milk, maize, beans and vegetables which are all sold locally. She also earns income from her business of selling fish to the local market. 

She is 50 years old and married with 6 children who are all adults. Her youngest child is currently attending school.

She recently repaid her fifth loan from Juhudi Kilimo and has requested this loan of 50,800 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow and expand her poultry farm. By adding another dairy cow and expanding her poultry farm, she hopes it will increase her income which in turn will enable her pay college fees for her children. 

Her biggest challenges have been fluctuation in the market prices of products and the high cost of poultry feeds. She hopes to set up a zero grazing unit in the future so that her animals can be well catered for. She also hopes to acquire a high-breed dairy cow in the future. 

She comments that Juhudi loans have benefited her very much. She also gives a thumb up for the current efficiency in terms of loan processing.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow, and expand her poultry farm.

loans.name: Kito Development Group 1-Mukono

texts.en: Thirty-year-old Fathilia K. is naturally a lighthearted, upbeat and industrious businesswoman who has been operating a fruit and vegetable enterprise in Kirinya-Mukono for the last 5 years. She says that she relied on financial help from her husband to get established. Previously she ran a charcoal sales business. Fathila says that she makes a weekly profit of 100,000 UGX. She plans to use this loan to buy more pineapples, passion fruits, paw-paws and jack fruit for resale. Fathilia has no children.

loans.use: to purchase more pineapples, passion  fruits, paw-paws and jack fruit

loans.name: William

texts.en:
William C. is 46 years old, married to Pyllis Chemwetich, and is a father of four. He has been in the dairy farming business for the last three years.

From this business, William gets a monthly profit of Kshs 4500. With the loan of Kshs 20000, he intends to buy a dairy cow worth Kshs 18000. The remaining Kshs 2000 will be used to purchase dairy feed.

William intends to use the business' profit to buy more dairy heifers and cows in order to increase his income.

As this is his first loan with Kadet, William hopes that he will be able to pay back the loan and borrow more in the future to expand his dairy farm.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Freshina Wanjiru

texts.en:
Freshina Wanjiru is 27 years old and has a husband named Joseph. Together they have four children. She has been running her boutique for 6 years with a monthly income of Kshs 14400.

This will be Freshina's third loan with Kadet, and she has repaid the previous ones well. She wants to use the loan to buy a motorbike in order to start a transport business. She hopes to expand the business and create employment for other people.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to start a transport business

loans.name: Kito Development Group 2-Mukono

texts.en: Twenty-nine-year-old Betty N. has a penchant for hard work. Over the last 11 years, this disposition has been of paramount importance in the smooth running of her beauty salon business in Kito-Mukono. Hard work is something she has been stressing, especially about the work of her workers. This business generates 180,000 shillings for Betty weekly.  By her own account, this married mother of two says it is a business that she began with a friend’s persuasion. With this loan, she says she is anticipating the purchase of more cosmetics to use at her beauty salon.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics for her beauty salon

loans.name: Constance

texts.en:
Constance N.  lives in Naguru, a neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has  3 children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (three of her sister's children).  

Constance has a business selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works 7 days out of every week.  

Constance sells her products at the market by means of wholesale/retail.  Constance has requested a loan of 2000000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal.  She also generates additional income through a small retail shop.

The main business challenge for  Constance is the rainy season which makes village roads impassable.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling wholesale only. 

Constance lives in a home that she rents.  She has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include food, rent, and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Najma

texts.en:
Najma is a married woman with four children, two of whom attend school, while two are too young for school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are electricity bills, school fees and food for the family. 

She operates her business of selling bedsheets, window curtains, and handbags. In addition, she sells charcoal to contribute to her other source of income. 

Najma faces a major challenge of delayed payments by creditors who purchase goods on credit. She hopes to build houses for rent in the future. 

With the Kshs 50,000 she wants to purchase two bundles of bedsheets, window curtains, and handbags. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy bedsheets, window curtains, and handbags for resale

loans.name: Gitau

texts.en:
Gitau is 62 years old and married to Ann. Together, they have five dependent children. He has been in the food service business for twenty years with an income of Kshs 12800. 

This is his first loan, which he intends to use to buy more stock of of flour, rice, and sugar. He hopes to improve his family's standard of living and buy a plot of land to build rental houses.

loans.use: To buy more stock of flour, rice, and sugar.

loans.name: Rose Wanjiru

texts.en:
Rose is 50 years old and married to James N.. They have three children and her spouse contributes towards the family income. She has been running her shop for 16 years with an income of Kshs 11,500 per month. 

She has a good history with KADET and is applying for her third loan which she intends to use to buy stock of flour, bar soaps, and liquid detergent to sell. She hopes to buy a piece of land for the family.

loans.use: To buy flour, bar soap, and detergent to resell

loans.name: Wambui

texts.en:
Wambui K. is 34 years old and married to Patrick who contributes to the family income. Together they have two children. She has been running her business for five years with a profit of about 10,000 KES per month.

This is her first loan with KADET, which she plans to use to buy two bags of sugar and a dozen bags of tea leaves. She hopes to expand her business and become a wholesaler.

loans.use: To expand the business by buying two bags of sugar and a dozen bags of tea leaves.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma A. lives in the Naguru neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has 7 children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (two orphans ).  

Fatuma has a business selling fruits and vegetables.  She has been in this business for less than one year, and she works 7 days out of every week. Fatuma sells her products at the market, by means of wholesale/retail.  Fatuma has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more boxes of oranges, Mangoes, pineapples and cabbages.  

She also generates additional income through selling piped water and computer services.  The main business challenges for Fatuma include seasonality and thieves.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling on wholesale only and start going directly to farmers . Fatuma lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and has access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food, medication and school fees .

loans.use: To buy more boxes of oranges, cabbages, mangoes  and pineapples.

loans.name: Edwin

texts.en:
Edwin owns and runs Aric electronics shop.  He started this business which is located in a very competitive environment two years ago.  In his shop, he also does repairs on electrical appliances.  

Being a member of Genesis group in Faulu Kenya, he has been guaranteed a loan of 30,000 KES by the members.  He will use the loan to buy a welding machine and a work station machine.  Edwin hopes to have an electronic workshop and become financially independent in the future.

loans.use: To buy a welding machine and a work station machine

loans.name: James Wainaina

texts.en:
James is a single 26-year-old man. He has a restaurant which he has been running for the past four years from which he earns a monthly profit of about Kshs 12500.

He intends to use this loan to expand his stock of flour, rice and sugar for use in his restaurant. 

In the future he hopes to use his savings to expand his business to accommodate the increasing number of clients. In addition, he hopes to buy a plot of land to grow the business and create employment.

loans.use: To buy flour, rice, and sugar

loans.name: Wycliffe

texts.en:
Wycliffe is a 32 year-old married man.  He runs a cafeteria to earn a living.  He was previously employed before he went into business.  He has been able to employ two people in his business.  He hopes to own a chain of hotels in five years.  

He has been guaranteed a loan of 30,000 Kes by Mayo Kenya group in Faulu Kenya.  This is his first loan from Faulu Kenya and he plans to add stock of maize flour and cereals. The photo has been taken in his busy cafeteria.

loans.use: To buy maize flour and cereals

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more used shoes to resell

loans.name: Dembe Women's Group-Mukono

texts.en: Despite her single marital status, 50-year-old N. Margret has not wavered from principles she says have made her the respectable woman that she is. Being uncompromisingly diligent and standing strong in the face of financial adversity have been winning hallmarks in the execution of her fish sales business. She has been in business for the last five years, and her business is situated in Nasuti-Mukono. She earns 150,000 shillings in profits. With this loan she says she is going to purchase more fish for reselling.

loans.use: To purchase more fish for resale

loans.name: Ryamatumba Twimukye-Bushenyi Group

texts.en: Ryamatumba Twimukye is the group to which 52-year-old John M. belongs. He has been operating his cattle sales business for five years. This business has been earning this productive gentleman 160,000 shillings weekly. On the side, John has an agro-sales business where he sells mostly bananas, cassava and sweet potatoes. John is married and has 6 children. He says that, with this loan, he is going to purchase more cows that he eventually hopes to resell.

loans.use: To buy more cows

loans.name: Hadjah

texts.en:
Hadjah B. lives in the Kilokore neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has three children, two of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members. 

Hadjah has a business selling clothes.  She has been in this business for seven years, and she works 5 days out of every week. Hadjah sells her products in a shop, by means of retail. 

Hadjah has requested a loan of 800,000 from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of second-hand clothes. She also generates additional income through tailoring. 

The main business challenges for Hadjah include transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to make her businesses more profitable by importing clothes herself. 

Hadjah lives in a home that she owns.  She doesn't have access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and food.

loans.use: To buy clothes for resale

loans.name: Rita Del Carmen

texts.es: Rita del Carmen C. D. L. H. vive con su Cónyuge en el barrio Los Olivos, ubicado al Sur Occidente D. BarranquilL. y tiene dos hijos en las edades D. 33 y 34 años.  Allí se dedica a L. venta D. refrescos como bolis (bebida congelada a base D. frutas naturales) chicha D. maíz y D. arroz, pony malta, gaseosas y cervezas que le ofrecen un 15% D. utilidad. Inicio su negocio cuando su esposo sufrió una enfermedad cerebral, por lo que debió tomar las riendas D. su hogar. Este es   crédito número 20 con L. Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con el  planea levantar una habitación adicional en su casa, así  quedarán mas cómodos con su negocio D. refrescos, su familia, sus clientes y elL. misma . Con los financiamientos recibidos por parte D. esta organización, sus hijos han logrado estudiar, su negocio se fortaleció y aumentó su autonomía; ahora su sueño es ahorrar para mejorar las condiciones físicas D. su vivienda y organizar una tienda donD. las familias encuentren artículos D. primera necesidad, se sientan satisfechos por su servicio y regresen por esta misma razón. Su mayor desafío relacionado con su negocio ocurrió en el año 1995 cuando se quemaron sus enfriadores, por un alto voltaje causado por un mal manejo D. las conexiones eléctricas que hizo un vecino y Rita tuvo que asumir unos gastos inesperados que casi termina con su negocio. Pero eso es una experiencia del pasado y ahora está muy contenta con lo que este le significa en su vida.
texts.en:
Rita del Carment C. D. L. H. lives with her husband in Los Olivos neighborhood, in the south-west of BarranquilL..  She has two children aged 33 and 34.  She works selling soft drinks such as 'bolis' (a frozen, natural-fruit-based drink), corn and rice 'chicha', Pony Malta, sodas and beers which give her a 15% profit.  She started her business when she discovered that her husband was suffering from a brain disease and she had to take over the reins in their household. 

This is her 20th loan with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo and she plans to use it to add a room to her house so that they will be more comfortable with her soft drinks business, her family, her customers and herself.  With the loans she has received from this organization, her children have managed to study, her business has become stronger and she has increased her independence.  Now her dream is to save so that she can improve the physical condition of her home and organize a store where families can find basic household goods, feel satisfied with her service and return to her store for that same reason.

Her greatest business challenge was in 1995 when her chiller cabinets burned as a result of high voltage caused by bad electrical connections which a neighbor had installed.  Rita had to cover unexpected expenses which almost finished off her business.  However, this experience is in the past and now she is very happy with what her business means in her life.

loans.use: Conversion of premises

loans.name: Hamida

texts.en:
Hamida K. lives in the Kilokore neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has one child, who isn’t in school. 

Hamida has a business making and selling chapatti and samosas.  She has been in this business for five years, and she works 7 days out of every week. 

Hamida sells her products in a shop, by means of retail.  Hamida has requested for a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more cartons of baking flour, cooking oil and cow peas.     

The main business challenge for Hamida is seasonality.  Her goals and aspirations are expanding her business so that she could start distributing them to different shops, and also to buy a plot of land.   

Hamida lives in a home that she rents.  She has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent.

loans.use: To buy baking flour, cooking oil, and cow peas

loans.name: Juan Carlos

texts.es:
En un local de su vivienda familiar, donde se ofrecen mercancías como ropa, sandalias, accesorios femeninos, detalles para el hogar, permanece Juan Carlos haciendo ofertas, vendiendo comprando, registrando pedidos entre otras actividades propias de lo que es su trabajo en la "Miscelánea Yullis" de su propiedad. Él es un joven soltero  de 21 años,  que creó desde hace 5 años, esta unidad de comercialización de su propia inspiración, por la necesidad de ayudar a los gastos propios y de su familia. Hoy ha logrado sostenerla y cumplir esta meta, pero se ha entusiasmado y quiere seguir creciendo en infraestructura y a nivel personal como microempresario, por eso ha acudido a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo donde, con el actual crédito, ha recibido 2; con este su credikiva, comprará jeans suéteres, camisas, calzado informal, y útiles de papelería entre esquelas, borradores, lapiceros, sacapuntas y accesorios femeninos, porque se prepara para Diciembre, época que por su experiencia sabe que se incrementarán las ventas y estará con esta inversión preparado para ello. Con la Fundación no solo ha recibido crédito sino también asesoría y capacitación en el mejoramiento de su desempeño administrativo, a eso se debe su entusiasmo porque aplica lo que aprende y le ha ido muy bien.
Su sueño mas adelante es tener otro punto de venta y mejorar las condiciones habitacionales de su vivienda, porque vive en nuevo milenio, un barrio de mucha gente trabajadora y rodeado de   actividades comerciales y su espacio físico debe estar adecuado para que su familia el y los clientes se sientan confortables
texts.en:
Juan Carlos has a business in his family home.  He sells goods such as clothes, sandals, women's accessories and items for the home.  Juan Carlos buys, sells, makes offers and records orders, amongst other activities, in his business which is called “Miscelánea Yullis”.  He is 21 years old and single.  He set up his sales unit 5 years ago on his own initiative as he needed to help with his own expenses and those of his family.  Today he has managed to sustain his business and accomplish his goal but he is enthusiastic and would like to continue growing in infrastructure and on a personal level as a small businessman.  For this reason he has come to Fundación Mario Santo Domingo.  This is his second loan.

With this Kiva loan he will buy jeans, sweaters, shirts, casual footwear and stationery items such as note paper, erasers, pens, pencil sharpeners and women's accessories because he is getting ready for December, a time when, he knows through experience, sales will increase.  With this investment he will be ready for it.  He has not only received loans from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo but also advice and training in improving his administrative performance.  This is what has caused his enthusiasm to apply what he has learned and he has done very well.

His future dream is to have another sales location and to improve the condition of his home because he lives in a neighborhood surrounded by many working people, surrounded by business activities and he would like his physical space to be suitable for his family, himself and his customers to feel comfortable in.

loans.use: To buy jeans, sweaters, shirts, casual footwear and stationery items such as note paper, erasers, pens, pencil sharpeners and women's accessories

loans.name: Hannah Adjoa Begyina

texts.en:
Hannah Adjoa Begyina A. sells provisions in Elmina. Hannah has received junior high school education. She is married to a mason and has three children. She assists her husband in the care of their children. Her loan will be used to buy more of her goods to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to further her children’s education.

In this photo, Hannah is sitting beside some bags of rice, boxes of canned tomatoes, gallons of oil and other things.

loans.use: To buy more of her goods to sell

loans.name: Dina

texts.es:
Dina forma parte del banco comunal “La Hermandad” de la comuna de Maipú. Ella vende ropa de lencería, ropa deportiva, juguetes y  hierbas medicinales en un puesto en una feria de su comuna, la cual se instala en 3 lugares diferentes. Trabaja 4 días a la semana, incluyendo todos los fines de semana, desde hace 18 años. Además Dina confecciona productos para temporadas definidas, con su máquina de coser, por ejemplo: en fiestas patrias hace trajes típicos y para navidad hace manteles y servilletas. Dina comparte el puesto en la feria con su hija , quien vende muñecas. 
Con este préstamo Dina comprará lencería. Su sueño es tener más clientes para aumentar sus ventas.
